description.text:
We never have enough cubicle hooks at work, so here's a parametric version.
The openscad file is composed of two parts: the base hook itself, and whatever you want to build onto it.  The piece as-designed is to hold some headphones.

Print; cleanup; use!
[2011-07-28] Added "cubical_hook_with_loop"; this has a hook at the bottom to hang the headphone cable on.
[2012-08-02] Added "newcube_hook"; we have some new cubicles, so time for a new hook.

A tool for making consistent and perfectly square cuts in balsa wood.

Get yourself some 1/2" by 1/2" extruded aluminum C angle for the handle, some skate bearings, some screws and nuts, then print out the hinges, the pivot point, and the blade holder. Mount that all to a nice solid board and you've got yourself a sweet balsa wood spar cutter. More info can be found on my blog.

title: Keurig Coffee Pour Over Adapter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pour over coffee adapter for using Keurig refillable coffee filter. I was thinking that Keurig Coffee Makers forces the water out too fast, using more coffee ground then needed. So I made this adapter to do a pour over myself... this does require some patience since it doesn't hold much water.   
Pictured print is printed using ABS. It was the original design for one size cup only. The uploaded one has groves for cups up to 9.5cm wide diameter cup.  
Enjoy your coffee!
Print using ABS or PLA with support.

comments.text: I can really only ask "why?"... If you're buying your own ground coffee, why bother using a kcups thing? Just make your coffee in a normal coffee maker of your choosing... As for the "looking for a holder for kcups so we can just pour water over it", same deal... Why? If you're wanting similar flavors just buy the grounds for it and make it normally. If it's because of "Oh well they don't make what I want in that sort of thing", so? Find out what it is, and make it. A majority of flavored "hot drinks" can be easily made by just buying the flavored syrup and adding 2-3 ounces. Majority of the good ones can be bought at a Kroger and a decent brand is da Vinci. Coffee tastes better when made this way (aka by hand from scratch) anyway...
comments.author: HikariNoKitsune

comments.text: My wife and I were just talking about a similar idea.  I'd like to see something like this that would hold a k-cup pod in a compartment with a funnel on top so that one could use their pods by pouring microwaved or kettle heated water into it.  A portable or camping Keurig if you will.

Since the previous box (4x4 x2) doesn't print quite well on a ToM HBP, designing a smaller box seems a better use of time (than tinkering with curl issues).
This box holds 8 pieces per layer (2x4), stacked 4 pieces high.  While still reaching the edge of the platform, the corners of the box stay well inside the evenly heated area and so shouldn't curl.
Since the box is smaller, the text on the lid now isn't surrounded by so much empty space.

I believe the tolerances in this design should be correct now... However, if you want room for a paper board, you should modify the SCAD file and add a few mm inside height. I've also uploaded a 2-plate piece set; it's just the original 4-plate pieces reorganized to fit better on the HBP. Many thanks to cymon for the original pieces and helping to work through designs! 2011-07-27; Haven't printed anything yet, but the hypothesis is good. 2011-07-28; Printed the lid: no corner curling; adhesion is good! 2011-07-31; Uploaded new files with better tolerances. 2011-08-02; Removed piece plate; use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10500 instead.

This is just a placeholder for an ongoing project to cheaply (from 3D printed parts and hardware store parts) make a purely mechanical single wavelength ellipsometer for surface measurement and analysis.  Additional wavelengths (as well as angles of incidence or AOI's) could also be sampled by using laser modules of other known wavelengths.

Current BOM is as follows:
  • Printed Items
    • 1.1 (10) 90 deg Threaded Rod Connectors
    1.2 (2) Eyehole Threaded Rod Connectors
    1.3 (1) AOI Arm
    1.4 (1) Right AOI ARM
    1.5 (1) "ThreadRod_Connect_90deg_0_25in-20-SmoothRodModFront-v2.stl"
    1.6 (2) "Spacer_Plates"
    1.7 (1) "Optics_Mounts_Photocell"
    1.8 (2) "Polarizer_Mounts_Laser_v2", (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:98556)
    1.9 (2) Rotatable Polarizer Mount Assemblies (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:98556).
  • Non-Printed Items
    2.1 (1) Protractor
    2.2 (13?) 1/4-20 Threaded Rods
    2.3 (25) 1/4-20 Hex Nuts
    2.4 (10) M3-0.5x16MM Socket Cap Screws
    2.5 (8) M3-0.5 Nuts
    2.6 (1) Laser Module (http://www.scientificsonline.com/diy-red-laser-pointer.html)
    2.7 (2) Polarizing Filters (http://www.sciplus.com/p/POLARIZING-FILTER-IN-REMOVABLE-MOUNT_48927)
    2.8 (1) CdS PhotoCell (Radio Shack?)
    2.9 (1) Multimeter that measures resistance
    2.10 (1) Circular Polarizing Filter (http://www.amazon.com/Tiffen-46CP-46mm-Circular-Polarizer/dp/B00004ZC8Y/ref=sr_1_31?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1371667297&sr=1-31&keywords=circular+polarizing+filter). This should fill the role of a quarter wave plate compensator
    • There will also be various tools and craft implements you will need to use.

  • Setup Procedure:

  • Calibration Procedure

  • Notes on data analysis
    • 5.1 References: 5.1.1 A User's Guide to Ellipsometry by Harland G. Tompkins (available on Amazon). 5.1.2 The Measurement, Instrumentation and Sensors Handbook (Electrical Engineering Handbook-CRC), 2 volume set by John G. Webster (Dec 29, 1998)-available on Amazon * Update 06/20/13 ** Added an extra optic mount on left and right Angle Of Incidence arms to allow for mounting a circular polarizer on either side (depending on the desired configuration). This is to allow for a null ellipsometer configuration. * Update 06/28/13 ** 2nd mechanical mock-up (had to reverse the order of the stack and place the sample behind the main axis), and first light-up test to make sure the laser module works. I decided to switch back to a Stokes polarimeter configuration (Polarizer-Sample-Analyzer). This will require only 4 intensity measurements (0, 90, and +/-45 degrees analyzer rotation only) to solve for Psi/Del. * Update 07/03/13 ** -Reworked the mechanical stack to hopefully minimize parallax error in measuring AOI. A picture of this mock-up was uploaded. I should probably add more supports to make frame more rigid. -Completed 1st draft of polarizer calibration procedure. Uploaded pdf print of this. -Completed 1st draft data sheet for collecting relative intensity measurements that will produce Psi/Del data. Started work on theoretical filmstack sheet (starting with bare substrate) to convert known dispersion to a theoretical Psi/Del trajectory (versus variation in AOI) which measured results can be regressed to. * Update 07/12/13 ** Took some time out from hardware development to work on some theory. Attached is an updated data spreadsheet that also contains a single-layer Psi/Del model that will allow the user to manually regress their measured results (to minimize the various error measures shown in the sheet) to determine the film optical properties. The data sheet shows SiO2 with no film since I plan next to perform the polarizer calibrations on a glass slide with a black backing (to prevent backside reflections). Update 01/13/14
    Started work again after a significant hiatus (sorry, I have been a little busy). As you can see from the latest picture, the appartus has undegone some evolution that I still need to document. Started Polarizer, "A", calibration. Still need to do Polarizer "B" before I can start 1st real data collection for analysis. Update 03/04/14
    Posted my first test data using a (not clean) microscope coverslip. The data curves appeared similar for +45 degree polarizer position (less so for -45 degrees polarizer position). From this 1st data set, there appears to be significant sources of error and need to better test repeatability (manual data collection is time comsuming). Posted a screen shot of the data compared to model with y-axis shifting (add or subtract) to Psi and Del values to minimize error to model and x-axis shifting to compensate for AOI measurement errors.

This is a 'cartoon' model of an Alcubierre Warp Drive which I drew in 123D CAD. I call it a cartoon model because I drew it from memory of what the artists renditions look like of this model. I fully intend to do a mathematically accurate model at some point.
This prints horizontally and will require support since the outside ring and the spokes don't touch the build surface but the center ellipsoid does.
And... here's a video of the build on my Thing-O-Matic:http://youtu.be/ntpW6BziKEk
Needs to have RAFT and FULL SUPPORT.

title: Tweeter Mount for Gen 5/S197 Ford Mustang (48/58mm tweeter)

description.text:
Designed for a friend.  For Hybrid Audio L1 Pro R2 tweeters. (48 mm diameter threaded main body, 58 mm face)  Should fit any GEN 5/S197 Ford Mustang, but was designed using a sail panel for a 2014 model.  Used a self-built FreeLSS-based 3D Scanner to model the sail panel surface profile, cleaned it up in MeshLab and MeshMixer, then imported into Sketchup to create the back side profile.  This file is for the right pod, print a mirrored version for the left.  You'll have to rotate it in your favorite print control software so you can print flat ring-side down.
The intention is that the pod will be lightly sanded, painted, (and repeat) until a nice finish is achieved.

remixed_from.author: tdeagan
remixed_from.title: Wade's Extruder Vertical Stand (for Bowden mod)

description.text: I've tried a couple other Hot End Bowden conversions, but none fit the pneufit-type fitting I used. I decided to start from scratch in OpenSCAD and make my own. First step was creation of a dimensionally accurate Ubis model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:103189). I used this with measurements from the Printrbot and pneufit adapter: SPC-06-01 Pneumatic Push to Connect Fitting. This fitting uses a British Standard Pipe Taper Thread R1/8". Tap size is 8.4mm for this thread, but I'm 'self' tapping with the thread itself into the plastic. I'm using 9.45mm for the base and 9.15 for the tip (it tapers.) I bought these from eBay (http://www.ebay.com/itm/Pneumatic-ONE-Push-In-Touch-to-Connect-Straight-male-Threaded-1-8-Tube-OD-6mm/290736473017?_trksid=p5197.m1992&_trkparms=aid%3D111000%26algo%3DREC.CURRENT%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D14%26meid%3D8383794446985907354%26pid%3D100015%26prg%3D1006%26rk%3D1%26sd%3D290736473017%26) I also used this fitting on my vertical extruder stand for the other side of the Bowden setup (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:96940).

The pictured (and workign great!) item was printed at .8 infill.  It used an earlier version of the model that had a thinner base and needed washers to make up the difference.  The downloadable model has been reworked to be the proper height.

author: andoni22

description.text:
Used Espresso grinds have to go somewhere!  
Knockboxes can start at $30 each... but you can make one at home for the cost of a flexi-straw, a screw, and an old coffee can!  
Note that because there is no shock absorption, this could damage your portaholder or filter baskets. So far, I haven't noticed any damage to my own equipment, but your mileage may vary.  
Flexi-straws are food-safe, but if it cracks, it could expose the non-safe screw underneath. For maximum safety, I recommend using a stainless steel screw. Warning: I do not guarantee the food safety of this Thing.

You will need:
1) Empty coffee can
2) 5" long stainless steel screw and matching nut
3) Flexi-straw
4) Scissors
5) Drill Instructions:
  • Drill holes near top of coffee can.
  • Cut flexi-straw to fit over the long screw.
  • Slide screw through side of the coffee can,
    covering the threads with the straw.
  • Attach nut.
  • Knock the coffee out of your portafilter!

print_settings.Infill:: 50% on Z Axis Parts & 30% on XY Axis

description.text:
I'm starting to print parts now. The LM8UU bearings fit perfectly so far. the 8mm rods are pretty tight. If you find that need something a little different. Let me know. Currently set for 15.5mm diameter for LM8UU 15mm OD bearings, and 8.15mm diameter for 8mm OD Rods. I had wanted to try a Funbot with 8mm Rods and Bearings, So here's my attempt at making that happen. This is just the parts required to redo the axis to 8mm. Download the other files from this link. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:560343/#files This is also modified to also be able to use a T8 Leadscrew on the Z axis. All parts are printed and fit well. Time to start assembly. (Everything has worked well, but I was 0.05mm off on the T8 nut mount. Doesn't effect you if you were using M8 nut like the original. I uploaded a new version of the Z carriage that fixes it. 10/26/15) I think It's all good now. I will add accessories from here on out. 10/27/15 Added 5/16" ID Bronze Bushing to lm8uu bearing adapter to allow use of 5/16" smooth rods with this machine. The Bronze Bushings have a 5/16" ID 7/16" OD and .062” Flange. 10/27/15 Added Bowden Extruder Support This is the current Bowden Extruder I'm using, and like it really well.
I use the standard Mk8 hobbed pulley one.
Compact Bowden extruder, direct drive, bearing bloc, auto load 1.75mm filament
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:669459 11/10/15 I added a Hotend mount with Inductive Auto Bed Leveling Sensor. This is designed for the Chinese metal hotends. The inductive sensor is offset in the Y direction 23mm. The NPN inductive sensor is wired directly to the RAMPS board (Brown to 12v, Black to Ground, and Blue to Z Min Signal Pin) Picture added. 12/03/15 Added Funbot M8 Marlin Firmware. It's set for 200 step motors with 16x microstepping with 20T GT2 pulleys on X and Y axis. TR8 Leadscrew on Z axis and Mk8 Gear on Extruder. It's also set for Auto Bed Leveling. 12/04/15 Added Funbot M8 Slic3r Configs. Hopefully it will give you a leg up on tuning your printer. 12/04/15 Added a Bill of Materials. I will adjust it a bit more soon. 12/17/15 Added Y Endstop Wing Nut I use for Y Belt tensioning
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:495543 Wing Nut I use for Bed Mount / Leveling
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:19812 Base Plate / Build Plate Options.
You can either use a premade Aluminum Base Plates found on ebay and Mk2/3 Heatbeds or use 200mm or 8" square wood or Aluminum base plates. I use 8" square 1/8" thick Aluminum plates for the build plate. If you want to add heat to it I suggest a 160mm Diameter Kapton Heater mounted on the bottom of the build plate. The Kapton Heatbed combo will heat to 90C in about 6 minutes.

comments.text:
e_steps_per_mm = (motor_steps_per_rev x driver_microstep) / (hob_effective_diameter x pi)
ie
e_steps_per_mm= (200 x 16) / (8 x 3.14159)

description.text:
This is a simple propeller balancer which can be used to balance plastic propellers for quadcopters using sticky tape. Two drops of oil are needed for better performance to reduce friction between plastic and metal axis of the propeller holder.
4 holes for M4 screws are made to connect balancer to solid surfaces.
IMPORTANT: the improved version of this propeller balancer is uploaded as version 2. 45 degree cuts are added to reduce friction instead of using oil. Note: print speed was 100 mm/s for Printrbot simple wood, therefore there are some small but visible defects.

description.text: Larger and more complex parts require greater accuracy in 3d printer calibration, especially with regard to laying down the first layer. This calibration part will help you ensure your print head is always the right height above your built plate, regardless of where it is in the XY plane. A level build plate seems to be the result of a skill you develop the more you use your 3d printer. Using a calibration print allows you to achieve greater accuracy than with a spirit level or the human eye. Remember to print this part at the lower end of your polymer's temperature range. Very runny PLA is more forgiving of miss-calibrated build plates. More discussion over http://www.woodsmokeworkshop.com/wordpress/?p=209

• print
  • tweak
  • repeat

title: Adjustable phone holder for tripod quick release

description.text:
This is and adjustable tripod phone holder for a tripod, with the an optional power bank holder.
Haven't printed this yet, so the tolerances are not tested.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

15

For springs or for springs and power bank Requirements:
4x M3 screws with bolds
4x springs that fits the above screws
1x M8 screw with bold
1x spring that fits the above screw
(+1 Rubber band optional to hold the power bank) Instructions:
  • Print either "for-springs" or "for-springs&power-bank".
  • Use the M3 screws and bolds and the springs for the holders that hold the phone from the back and the front.
  • Use the M8 screw and bold and the spring for the holder that holds the phone from side to side.
  • Glue the base to the rest.
    • For rubber of for rubber and power bank Requirements:
    6 Rubber bands
    (+1 Rubber band optional to hold the power bank) Instructions:
  • Print either "for-rubber" or "for-rubber&power-bank".
  • Print 1x the "column-for-rubber" in the original size
  • Print 2x the "column-for-rubber" a little bigger than the size of the phone
  • Use the rubber bands between holders of the phone.
  • Glue the base to the rest.
In Sketch up, I attached the file

Feel free to edit the files.
The design is provided "as is"

UPDATED - Finished. Enjoy! Please post pictures of your prints.  
The new Apple Airport Extreme / Time Capsule (2013) is almost exactly the same proportions as the Tardis. Starting with OZAR's 'Actual Tardis', I removed / replaced the non-manifold fonts and did a lot of reworking of the rest of the mesh in Blender, including lots of tweaks to make it  print better when large. I looked at iFixIt's teardown and created venting in the base to maintain the fan driven airflow of these units.

Print with no raft or supports, I print at the standard .20mm layer height, although you would get a quicker and just as acceptable print at 0.27mm. Give your printer a good once over before starting, this is a long print.  
I've been getting on better and better with Blender, initially an impenetrable fortress of hidden key strokes and confusing accidental mouse actions, having actual tasks to get done in Blender has helped me understand its full power. Included is a .blend file with 'live' boolean stacks still enabled, feel free to take a a look at how I have constructed this in sections, with vents, stacking keys and the void for the device removed, and then easily produced printable sections.  
Printing: This is a very large print, which is challenging, if you do print it, PICTURES PLEASE!!! And share how it went. Because of it's size, unless you are hotboxing expert, PLA only. Print time is long, approaching 20 hours total.  
Print out, brush off any excess on the fitting keys, and put it over your WiFi base station. Invite friends around, and casually drop it into conversation. Note their envy with glee!

comments.author: BillyJo182

comments.text: I do not have a warmer plate if that's what youre asking about the bed temp. My build temp is the only temp I set at 217 degrees. I do not use Makerbot PLA because I find it has more temperature issues than a pissed off girlfriend. I buy my PLA from http://Sainsmart.comSainsmart.com. 1.75mm PLA. I keep my build temp set at 217. It hardly ever has issues. I also always print on Low definition. The reason is... I've built 4 or 5 designs out of low, medium, and high to see the difference... and overall, I really don't see a difference in the quality settings. So I always build on low, and I always get great builds. I also keep my infill at 10%. I do not have one of the new time capsules, I had actually just found this because I wanted to print a tardis for my mom because she is in love with Dr. Who. And this was the sweetest/hardest one I could find. (Go big or go home?) So I started it. It took 5 hours for the lid, and 8 hours for the bottom half. First try, no fuck ups. It was fantastic. Let me know if you have any other questions, sorry this took so long for a response.

description.text:
In my office we have groups of 4 desks seperated with a fabric covered partition. A collegue of mine has these clips that have spikes in the back that go through the fabric as you can't use drawing pins (I assume under the fabric is MDF).
This is my take on that clip. I have yet to print it so don't know if it will work. The official one was made of two parts which have a spring to keep the jaw closed. I replaced that on this on with some plastic that I hope has enough flex in to work, it may need to be made thinner, currently it is 2mm thick.
-edit- Updated my apparently terrible typos!
Update 1
This doesn't work, the plastic PLA is too brittle to act as a spring in this format. I am currently working on a replacment design that may work.
Please DO NOT print this, it won't work :(

author: pavelgr

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fQhlhyf6nAO

This simplified model of an articulation or joint, will help teachers show kids (3-12) how muscles, bones, tendons hinged by articulations work. It is inspired by the elbow joint and it is meant to show how the arm moves.
The model requires additional tubes, preferably cardboard, and some long balloons (the type to build balloon animals out of), and optionally tape and latex glove to make the hand. This makes it ideal for crafts project for kids to do. 
It is customizable so it fits all tubes around the world.
The design includes a ring to tie the balloons to. I am opened to suggestions to make the model more anatomically accurate, or general improvements; like for example making a 3rd piece to help to tie the balloons on the opposite side of the tube of the joint. 
This model may also be used for engineering, but probably requires some modifications.

Step 0 printing Measure your tubes, inner tube Radius (diameter/2) is used for ConnectorR parameter. The wall/thickness of the tube is to be used as ConnectorOverlap parameter. Step 1 fit the two parts together Careful when joining the parts, as for, and depending on the printing quality and material, it may snap. Position one hand around the outer joint part (the spherical part), while gently pushing the inner part in with the other hand. Step 2 fit to tubes If printed with the correct parameters the pieces will be perfectly fitted to the tubes.
To ensure a more permanent fit use non-toxic glue. Cyanoacrylate based glue (like Super Glue) might not be the best option as it does not stick well with paper, and may dissolve your 3D-printed pieces; apppart from being toxic. Step 3 (Optional) decorate You may paint your model, before fitting the balloons (better not paint those). Make sure you use non-toxic paints that will stick both to the tubes and material used for the pieces. Another addition, may be a an inflated latex glove, use tape to fix it to the end of the tube. Another way is to push a toothpick through the tube and the knot of the glove (but make sure not to puncture the glove). Step 4 fit the muscles (balloons) It is recommended to use a red balloons, to act as muscles, most text books will depict muscles as red.
Fill a balloon so that the length of the inflated part is less than that of the tube. Push the inflated part to the middle, leaving 2 deflated "strings" on either sides. Tie (or tape) one side to the top of the tube (on the same tube, but opposite to the outer joint part, the spherical part). Make sure there is an appropriate tension, before tying the other to the space in the inner joint near to the tube (that is it's purpose). Repeat with the other muscle. For the opposite muscle (the triceps in the arm joint) make sure the balloon string goes through the channel around the top of the inner joint part (that is it's purpose). A single balloon for both muscles may be used. Balloons may be decorated with felt-tip pen, to show the muscle fibers and or veins and arteries.
Inspiration This thing was inspired by a co-worker of mine, and a crafts project she found (The 3D design is in fact an improvement for that project). Works used

copyright Chris Petersen, 2013
Licensed under LGPL and CC-SA
  • Thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:109467
  • Source https://github.com/dotscad/dotscad/blob/master/pie.scad

Objectives Demonstrate how muscles, bones, tendons hinged by articulations work. It is inspired by the elbow joint and it is meant to show how the arm moves. Audiences Teachers, and Kids from 3 to 12. Preparation The model requires additional tubes, preferably cardboard, and some long balloons (the type to build balloon animals out of) or rubber bands, and optionally tape and latex glove to make the hand. Steps Follow the Post-Printing section. Results The model shows how muscles pull bones together, and how articulations turn this pull into rotational motion. The difference in pull force between the muscles control the speed, force and direction of the rotational motion. The visualization of these mechanics will make it easier to understand how the body is able to move.

comments.author: alightbulb

comments.text:
Hello Amanda,
Nice to see there is interest in this thing.
There are 2 solutions I can think of:
1) reduce the parameter T (tolerance, set through customizer on the second tab), this means your printer is very well calibrated! or that default tolerance value I set is too big (I did add this after printing my model), you may print only the "mouthed" piece and recycle the other one.
2) increase the JointInW parameter (again in the customizer), and reprint only the inserted piece recycling the mouthed piece.

description.text: 65cm collapsible vuvuzela for all the World Cup fans out there. Ridiculously loud! Prints in 5 ~14.5cm (5.7in) tall segments. Will fit on almost any desktop printer and segments snap together. easily My fit is a little wiggly, but I'm printing in nylon which is not as stiff as ABS or PLA. Feedback on your fit appreciated! I'll probably improve the clips anyways. Collapses to under 40cm and locks in collapsed position Includes teardrop holes to attach a string/strap without the need for support I've included a multibody .sldpt file and a .step file. The .step includes a simple single body Vuvuzela. Feel free to make derivatives, changes, do whatever you like with it and have fun! Please link here and use share alike licensing if you post a derivative design. For those of you with very tall printers (>40cm), or if you want to mess around with something more complete than the single body .step; I'll be adding 2 .step's of the 2 collapsible sections. Stay tuned for updates, pics, a video, and more. If you have a question or interest, drop a comment. For sheet music and a recording, please follow the link for the lovely Vuvuzela Concerto in B Flat.

First things first: Credit to Beavertank for the original mod.
This is my remix of the Dropzone Commander scale building files, with extra options and side tabs removed for smoother construction. I found with the original that my printer made the tabs oversize, resulting in jagged building faces. These files have flat sides to make alignment more flexible.
These files are grouped by feature and will combine with the original designs vertically, should you wish. Now there are 3 full extra sets over the original files.

Printer:

M3D Micro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Low

Infill:

Low

Notes: Print standing up for best resolution. I found that rafts and supports weren't necessary for any of the parts. I print at 91% scale as that is closer to DZC cardboard building size, but that is just personal preference. On my Micro it takes about 30 mins for each rooflet, 40 mins for each middle floor part, 60 mins for each ground floor part.

Assembly Superglue parts together, I started with the roof (using sheet styrene instead of printing a large flat surface) and place a non-corner piece aligned with the roof panel edge. Then add pieces one-by-one around the edge to make the building, then add floors one by one. Alternatively, glue parts to a piece of foamcore to build a side, for each side. Then add a roof. Remember to leave gaps at each end for the foamcore!

3D Model of the Official Touchscreen for the Raspberry Pi. Attached includes a 3D model in SketchUp that contains a model of the touchscreen, and a case that is printed in 3 parts.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

10%

Notes: I printed the case at .3mm layer height to speed up printing, but I would suggest using .2mm or higher so that the angles come out better.

Assembly Required to assemble this case is either 12 #4-40x3/4" screws or 12 M3x18mm screws. First attach the bottom layer to the touchscreen, then the middle to the bottom, and finally the top to the middle. This case is only designed to fit if the Raspberry Pi is inverted upside down like in the pictures above.

I designed these for myself and my students. The D12 has a different musical key on each face, the D4 has a different basic chord quality (so major, minor, diminished, and augmented), and the D6 has different seventh chord qualities (major, minor, dominant, diminished, half diminished, and major-minor). So if you're practicing seventh chords, for example, you'd roll the D12 and the D6 and then play F#7 (assuming that's what came up). The D12 is also useful by itself for practicing a chord progression in different keys or just as a creative tool for generating ideas. I have a YouTube channel where I upload music lessons, mostly centered around music theory concepts. I show off/talk about these dice a good bit in this video (although I also talk about my channel in general and my Patreon campaign, so be warned) https://youtu.be/AGsRm26uBwU Oh and if you're not familiar with the different symbols:
Triangle - major
Minus - minor
Circle - diminished
Circle with a Slash - half diminished (also known as minor7 flat-five)
Plus - augmented And of course you can always come check out my YouTube channel if you want to learn more :)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

.1mm

20

Notes: Of the 3, the D4 is the easiest to print (faces are angled upwards), the D12 is the hardest (faces are overhanging), and the D6 is about in the middle (faces are vertical). The D12 has a couple integrated supports, but you shouldn't need to turn supports on for any of them. I also recommend a good print cooling fan, otherwise the lettering will sag and just look crappy in general. Also, make sure you rotate the D12 so that the supports are facing downward. Thingiverse likes to display things as Z-forward Y-up, but most slicers seem to use Y-forward Z-up. So just be sure to rotate if needed. You can set the infill to whatever you like (as long as it's not zero). More infill = heavier dice. At 20% they're pretty light, but I like the way they feel. At 70-80% the D12 gets pretty clunky feeling when you're throwing it around. The other two are fine though.

I think it may have had something to do with it being centered about z=0 instead of entirely in positive-z space because I got a nicely finished bottom half plus a ratsnest of filament that couldn't adhere to the empty space very well ;-) Should have looked more closely at the preview! description.text: Just a simple SD card Holder

This script takes text and makes it 3d. I know this has been done before but I thought this was a unique approach, so here it is. The script uses the Cairo and Pango libraries to render with whatever fonts you have installed (should be cross-platform though I have only tested on Linux). The thing that differentiates this approach most from others is that the text is anti-aliased. The latest code will always be here:
https://github.com/brad/text2surface NOTE: This suffers from the same size limitation as it's predecessor, so if you make the text too large OpenSCAD will crash when rendering it. I've found 70 to be a good font size for a sign that spans the build platform, so that's the default.
2011-09-30: Added ability to extrude non anti-aliased text.

[email protected]:~/code/text2surface$ ./text2surface.py --help
usage: text2surface.py [-h] [-l] [-r] [-t TEXT] [-f FONTNAME] [-s FONTSTYLE]
[-i FONTSIZE] [-d MAXDIM] [-z ZHEIGHT] [-o FILENAME] Convert text to a surface for OpenSCAD and a .stl if desired. optional arguments:
-h, --help show this help message and exit
-l List available font families and exit.
-r Remove base layer from surface. Only applies if exporting to
.scad and/or .stl.
-t TEXT The text to convert
-f FONTNAME The font family to use, to see a list of available fonts use
"-l"
-s FONTSTYLE The font style to use. Can be either "italic" or "bold"
-i FONTSIZE The font size to use
-d MAXDIM The maximum size in mm to make the x or y dimension. Only
applies if exporting to .scad and/or .stl.
-z ZHEIGHT The max z-height of the text, defaults to 5
-o FILENAME By default, this script just outputs textsurface.dat, which
can be imported into an OpenSCAD document. If you specify a
.scad filename for this parameter, the script will also output
a .scad file which imports the surface. If you specify a .stl
filename, the script will go further and generate a .stl file. ============================== Examples: reprap.stl (default text is RepRap)
./text2surface.py -f "URW Chancery L" -i 50 -o reprap.stl ubuntu.stl
./text2surface.py -f Ubuntu -i 50 -t Ubuntu -o ubuntu.stl polybot.stl
./text2surface.py -f "[F500]" -t polybot -o polybot.stl
